## Basic concepts

We are going to go through some basic models for population growth, in which age and most other features of real populations are disregarded. Other features ignored by these models are migration and changes in birth and death rates

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
A population count at time $t$ is denoted by $P_t$ when we use discrete values, or $P(t)$ over a continuum of time.
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
Let's start with a population of 4 rabbits in $t_   0=1950$.

![](images/rabbits2.jpg){.lightbox fig-align="center" width="50%"}
:::

## Linear growth

::: {columns}
::: {.column width="40%"}
We assume:

-   Population increases without limitations (resources, space, competition, environmental resistance) along time

-   The rate is constant, meaning every year, the population increases 10 individuals per unit of time 
$$
P(t)=4+10*(t-1950)
$$ 
:::

::: {.column width="\"60%"}
```{r}
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)
t <- data.frame(t= c(seq(1950,2100,10)))
p0 <- 4
t0 <- 1950

linear_g <- function(t,r){
  a <- p0
  result <- a+r*(t-1950)
  return(result)
}

t_linear <- t |> 
  mutate(P_lin = round(linear_g(t=t, r=1),0))

p_linear <- ggplot(data = t_linear, 
       aes(x=t, y=P_lin))+
  geom_line()+
  theme_bw()+
  labs(x = "t",
       y = "P(t)")

p_linear
```

```{r}
t_linear |>
  filter(t %in% c(1950,2020,2100)) |> 
  kbl() |> 
  kable_classic_2(full_width = F, html_font = "Verdana") |> 
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"))
```
:::
:::

## Exponential growth

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
We assume:

-    population increases without limitations (resources, space, competition, environmental resistance) along time

-   The rate is proportional to the current size at $t$ (meaning larger populations grow faster)

$$
P(t)=P(0)*e^{r(t-t_0)}
$$ If we derive this function, we get that the differential equation we get $P'(t)=P(0)*e^{rt}=r*P(t)$. This is important for the next model. <!-- Which is a J-shaped curve (as the $\mu(x)$ function) -->

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

```{r}

exponential_g <- function(t,r){
  result <- p0*exp(r*(t-t0))
  return(result)
}

t_exponential <- t |> 
  mutate(P_exp=exponential_g(t=t, r=.05))

p_exponential <- ggplot(data = t_exponential, 
       aes(x=t, y=P_exp))+
  geom_line()+
  theme_bw()+
  labs(x = "t",
       y = "P(t)")+
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(1950,2100))

p_exponential
```

```{r}
t_exponential |> 
  filter(t %in% c(1950,2020,2100)) |> 
  mutate(P_exp = round(P_exp,0)) |> 
  kbl() |> 
  kable_classic_2(full_width = F, html_font = "Verdana") |> 
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"))
```

:::

::::

## Logistic growth {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
We assume:

-   There are constrictions preventing population growing indefinitely
-   Initially, population grows exponentially but then stabilizes and $r$ will tend to $0$.
-   There is an ultimate population so that $lim_{t\to\infty} P(t)=a$ where $a$ is the "carrying capacity". 

```{r}
logistic_g <- function(t,r,a=150){
  # p0 <- 1000
  a/(1+(a-p0)/p0*exp(-r*(t-t0)))
}
# t_prev <- data.frame(t=c(1890,1900,1910,1920))
# t <- bind_rows(t_prev,t)

t_logistic <- t |> 
  mutate(P_log=logistic_g(t=t, r=.05))

p_logistic <- ggplot(data = t_logistic, 
       aes(x=t, y=P_log))+
  geom_line()+
  # geom_vline(xintercept=t0, linetype = "dashed")+
  theme_bw()+
  labs(x = "t",
       y = "P(t)")+
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(1950,2100))

p_logistic
```

:::

::: {.column width="40%"}

If we allow the previous derivative to "slow down" in its growth, we get $P'(t)=r*P(t)[1-\frac{P(t)}{a}]$

And we get the logistic model

$$
P(t)=\frac{a}{(1+e^{-r(t-t_0)})}
$$ So assuming $a=150$


```{r}
t_logistic |> 
  filter(t %in% c(1950,2020,2100)) |> 
  kbl() |> 
  kable_classic_2(full_width = F, html_font = "Verdana") |> 
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"))
```

:::

## Comparison on the long-term {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
-   *Linear model*: The population grows steadily by 10 bunnies a year in 2100 there are 154 bunnies.
-   *Exponential model*: The population doubles every 14 year approximately, leading to an explosive increase over time.
-   *Logistic model*: The population grows rapidly at first but the slows down as it approaches the carrying capacity.

```{r}
table <- left_join(t_linear,t_exponential, by = "t") %>% 
          left_join(t_logistic, by = "t") %>% 
mutate(across(P_lin:P_log, ~round(.,0)))

ggplot()+
geom_line(data=t_linear, mapping=aes(x = t, y=P_lin), color="green", text="linear",linewidth = 1.5)+
geom_line(data=t_exponential, mapping=aes(x = t, y=P_exp), color="blue", text="exponential",linewidth = 1.5)+
geom_line(data=t_logistic, mapping=aes(x = t, y=P_log), color="red", text="logistic",linewidth = 1.5)+
theme_bw()+
scale_x_continuous(limits=c(1950,2070))+
scale_y_continuous(limits=c(0,1000))+
labs(y="P(t)")
```
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

```{r}
table |> 
  kbl() |> 
  kable_classic_2(full_width = F, html_font = "Verdana") |> 
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"), font_size = 20)
```
:::
